channel.title: BBC News - Technology

item.title: Apple dealt major blow in Epic Games trial
item.description: A judge in the Apple vs Epic trial says Apple must give app developers alternative payment options.

item.title: 'Anti-radiation' phone stickers still sold on Amazon
item.description: Eight months ago a BBC investigation reported the smartDOT stickers had "no effect".

item.title: Fortnite video chat app Houseparty to close
item.description: The developers of the video chat app say they can no longer give it "the attention it deserves".

item.title: Texas passes social media 'de-platforming' law
item.description: The US state makes it illegal to ban somebody from social media because of their political views.

item.title: Elizabeth Holmes: Has the Theranos scandal changed Silicon Valley?
item.description: Could a Theranos scandal happen again or has Silicon Valley learnt its lesson?

item.title: Ray-Ban Stories: Facebook reveals its video camera glasses
item.description: Facebook and eyewear brand Ray-Ban have revealed a pair of glasses that contain two cameras.

item.title: Playstation Showcase 2021: What we learned
item.description: Sony attempts to turn fan frustration into excitement about new games.

item.title: Twitter to label 'good' bot accounts
item.description: Twitter wants "good" bot accounts to label themselves as non-human.

item.title: Amazon offers to pay college fees for 750,000 US staff
item.description: The online shopping giant says all US frontline workers will be eligible as it fights to attract new employees.

item.title: Three brings in EU roaming charges and ends global scheme
item.description: Three is the third UK network to bring back roaming charges for the EU post-Brexit.

item.title: PayPal raises fees between UK and Europe
item.description: PayPal is bringing in a new fee for commercial transactions between the UK and EEA.

item.title: Facebook accused of allowing sexist job advertising
item.description: An investigation by Global Witness suggests its algorithm is biased in choosing who sees which ads.

item.title: Is this the era of a more shopping focused social media?
item.description: Virtual retail is changing and becoming more embedded in our day to day online activities.

item.title: Esports: Why are there so few professional women gamers?
item.description: There are no female players in the top 300 earners in esports, according to research shared with BBC News.

item.title: Meet Digit, the workplace robot, and other news
item.description: BBC Click's Marc Cieslak looks at the best of the week's technology news.

item.title: Breast cancer: The AI tool trained to spot the disease
item.description: Artificial intelligence trained to spot the disease is tested at Nottingham University Hospital.

item.title: Little penguin feeding behaviour revealed with trackers
item.description: Ten males were fitted with sensors in the breeding season to give greater insight into the birds.

item.title: Could a reboot make social media a nicer place?
item.description: A Harvard University project will explore whether social media can be de-toxed

item.title: The Kenyans who are helping the world to cheat
item.description: Some Kenyans try to escape poverty by helping foreign students to fake their academic work.

item.title: The models that turned Instagram into their DIY catwalk
item.description: New York Fashion Week marks a tentative return - but how did supermodels keep working through Covid?

item.title: Why coders love the AI that could put them out of a job
item.description: Artificial intelligence is getting better at penning code but still a long way from working alone.

item.title: Has Covid killed off business cards for good?
item.description: Sales of business cards have fallen sharply as a result of the pandemic.

item.title: How to back up your data and keep it safe
item.description: Experts recommend using three drives to back up your data and using cloud-based services.

item.title: Can apps move the #MeToo movement forward?
item.description: Reporting sexual harassment at work is getting easier thanks to new technologies.
